awd_titl_txt: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: The Cretaceous World: Digitizing Fossils to Reconstruct Evolving Ecosystems in the Western Interior Seaway
awd_abstract_narration:
Between 65 and 100 million years ago, during the time that dinosaurs walked the earth, a large, tropical seaway covered the central part of what is now North America. This seaway teemed with marine life. Snails and clams lived on the seafloor; ammonites, along with giant mosasaurs, plesiosaurs, sharks, and fish, swam about; at the same time early birds and pterosaurs floated on or flew above the seaway. What remains today is a prolific fossil record that has been collected by paleontologists for over 100 years. Notable fossils from this time period and region are on display at museums around the world.  However, the vast bulk of fossils collected from this region are locked away in museum drawers. To provide scientists and the general public access to these fossils and their associated data, this project proposes to digitize invertebrate and vertebrate fossils from this time period and region, making information accessible through searchable electronic databases.  Additionally, a variety of online resources illustrating and describing these fossils and mapping their distributions will be developed. A freely accessible online textbook of paleontology will be generated and a website and App will be developed to highlight the appearances, occurrences, and ages of constituent species, to help students and aspiring paleontologists identify and learn about these fossils. The project plans to generate a variety of curricular materials for K-12 education, including 3-D scans of fossils for free download and printed 3-D models for classroom use. Products of this project will also include workshops to engage science teachers and items to augment public programs and exhibits at participating institutions. 

This work will greatly increase the scientific value of eight major U.S. museum collections of fossils. The museum collections contain large amounts of data useful for studying what causes marine species to migrate, go extinct, and evolve during a long period of greenhouse climate conditions similar to those our planet may soon experience. These data have relevance for evaluating how global change has and will continue to affect life on earth. An estimated 164,000 specimens collected from thousands of locations, in the region once occupied by the Western Interior Seaway, will be databased and georeferenced. Representatives from each of roughly 1,500 microfossil, invertebrate, and vertebrate species will be imaged. The digitized records will be made available online via individual museum databases, iDigBio, and iDigPaleo. The resultant data will enable scientists to answer questions about how different species interact and ecosystems change in the face of environmental shifts during a key time in the history of life. Moreover, the data will be ideal for use with an assortment of modern quantitative tools -including paleoecological niche modeling (PaleoENM) - and will help improve paleoclimate and paleoceanographic models. Finally, several undergraduate and graduate students will be trained. Results of the project will be published at the following url: www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org.

por.por_cntn:
A key outcome of our work has been greatly expanding the availability of data on fossil specimens in our collections.  As part of our work, we have databased more than 135,000 fossil specimens housed at the Biodiversity Institute, University of Kansas (KU).  Our partners at the South Dakota School of Mines & Technology (SDSMT) databased more than 58,000 specimens. Across our entire project and including all collaborators more than 475,000 specimens have been databased.  We at KU have also georeferenced (pinpointed occurrences on a map using latitude and longitude values) more than 9,900 fossil localities.  Our partners at the SDSMT georeferenced more than 900 localities, and more than 25,000 localities were georeferenced across the entire project as well. Throughout the course of the project more than 10,000 specimens in total were also imaged.  The specimen and locality data are shared via the web at www.iDigBio.org and www.GBIF.org , and the KU website https://biodiversity.ku.edu/invertebrate-paleontology/collections/collections-search .

 

The project also led to the publication of several research papers on patterns of marine fossil species distribution, extinction, and diversification. For instance, we used specimen data in conjunction with computer mapping software and statistical analyses to consider whether the abundance of a species or its geographic distribution is a better predictor of extinction resistance.  Typically, distribution is a better predictor, but we found evidence that at least during certain times abundance might be more important.  We also found that species with lower physiologies and associated activity levels tend to be more resistant to extinction.  Moreover, patterns of stability were examined in assemblages of marine species over the course of millions of years.  The individual species that occurred in any given assemblage were found to change through time; however, the overall composition of the assemblages did not change much.  Especially the total number of species that occurred in any given region and environment was found to be quite stable through time.  In addition, evidence for the origination of new marine species in the large seaway that ran through the central part of North America during the time of the dinosaurs was uncovered.  At the same time, several episodes of invasion of marine species into this seaway from regions outside of North America were also found to have occurred. 

 

The project also led to broader impacts and products for outreach.  For example, as part of the project at KU we trained and supported 1 post-doctoral fellow, 7 graduate students, and 3 undergraduate students.  At the SDSMT 3 graduate students were trained and supported.  Across the entire project, including all partners, in total more than 40 students at all levels were trained and supported.  We, along with our partners, also share information online about the many fossil species we databased through resources such as the Cretaceous Atlas of Ancient Life, https://www.cretaceousatlas.org/ , the Digital Atlas of Ancient Life, http://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/ , which has been receiving more than 200,000 visits a year, and also a new version of the app of the same name, https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/version-2-0-of-the-digital-atlas-of-ancient-life-app/ , that provides content for handheld devices and which in total has received more than 19,200 downloads.  The information we provide with these resources includes descriptions, images, and maps, making it possible for amateur fossil collectors and the general public to learn where to find fossils and how to identify them.  We also produced the Digital Atlas Identify app, https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/digital-atlas-app/ , which allows a user to take a picture of a fossil and send it to a paleontologist for identification. This app has been downloaded more than 6,000 times.  A new Digital Encyclopedia of Ancient Life, https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/learn/ , was also created that provides open access entries on numerous paleontological topics for a non-technical audience.  Lesson plans were also created by the SDSMT.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/12/2021
Modified by: K. Christopher Beard

por.por_txt_cntn:
A key outcome of our work has been greatly expanding the availability of data on fossil specimens in our collections.  As part of our work, we have databased more than 135,000 fossil specimens housed at the Biodiversity Institute, University of Kansas (KU).  Our partners at the South Dakota School of Mines & Technology (SDSMT) databased more than 58,000 specimens. Across our entire project and including all collaborators more than 475,000 specimens have been databased.  We at KU have also georeferenced (pinpointed occurrences on a map using latitude and longitude values) more than 9,900 fossil localities.  Our partners at the SDSMT georeferenced more than 900 localities, and more than 25,000 localities were georeferenced across the entire project as well. Throughout the course of the project more than 10,000 specimens in total were also imaged.  The specimen and locality data are shared via the web at www.iDigBio.org and www.GBIF.org , and the KU website https://biodiversity.ku.edu/invertebrate-paleontology/collections/collections-search .

 

The project also led to the publication of several research papers on patterns of marine fossil species distribution, extinction, and diversification. For instance, we used specimen data in conjunction with computer mapping software and statistical analyses to consider whether the abundance of a species or its geographic distribution is a better predictor of extinction resistance.  Typically, distribution is a better predictor, but we found evidence that at least during certain times abundance might be more important.  We also found that species with lower physiologies and associated activity levels tend to be more resistant to extinction.  Moreover, patterns of stability were examined in assemblages of marine species over the course of millions of years.  The individual species that occurred in any given assemblage were found to change through time; however, the overall composition of the assemblages did not change much.  Especially the total number of species that occurred in any given region and environment was found to be quite stable through time.  In addition, evidence for the origination of new marine species in the large seaway that ran through the central part of North America during the time of the dinosaurs was uncovered.  At the same time, several episodes of invasion of marine species into this seaway from regions outside of North America were also found to have occurred. 

 

The project also led to broader impacts and products for outreach.  For example, as part of the project at KU we trained and supported 1 post-doctoral fellow, 7 graduate students, and 3 undergraduate students.  At the SDSMT 3 graduate students were trained and supported.  Across the entire project, including all partners, in total more than 40 students at all levels were trained and supported.  We, along with our partners, also share information online about the many fossil species we databased through resources such as the Cretaceous Atlas of Ancient Life, https://www.cretaceousatlas.org/ , the Digital Atlas of Ancient Life, http://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/ , which has been receiving more than 200,000 visits a year, and also a new version of the app of the same name, https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/version-2-0-of-the-digital-atlas-of-ancient-life-app/ , that provides content for handheld devices and which in total has received more than 19,200 downloads.  The information we provide with these resources includes descriptions, images, and maps, making it possible for amateur fossil collectors and the general public to learn where to find fossils and how to identify them.  We also produced the Digital Atlas Identify app, https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/digital-atlas-app/ , which allows a user to take a picture of a fossil and send it to a paleontologist for identification. This app has been downloaded more than 6,000 times.  A new Digital Encyclopedia of Ancient Life, https://www.digitalatlasofancientlife.org/learn/ , was also created that provides open access entries on numerous paleontological topics for a non-technical audience.  Lesson plans were also created by the SDSMT.
